title: 103_s483
content:
The "Prisoner-of-War Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the issuance of 1,500,000 one dollar coins with specific specifications and design emblematic of American prisoners of war. The coins are legal tender and bear inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The coins authorized under the "Prisoner-of-War Commemorative Coin Act" can be issued from January 15, 1994, to December 31, 1994. The silver for these coins will be sourced from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities and will have a design emblematic of American prisoners of war. The design for coins authorized by the Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins will be sold as per the Act. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at face value plus costs and a $5 surcharge per coin. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will also receive a discount. The surcharge collected will be used as specified in the Act. The surcharges received from the sale of coins under this Act will be used as follows: $3,000,000 for the construction of the Andersonville Prisoner-of-War Museum in Georgia, 50% to the endowment fund, and 50% to maintain national cemeteries. The Secretary shall pay 50 percent of the remaining surcharges to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for maintaining national cemeteries. SEC. 8. ENDOWMENT FUND. An endowment fund is established in the Department of the Interior to be administered by the Secretary and consist of deposited amounts. The Secretary can invest the fund in US obligations to meet its needs. The Secretary of the Interior can use the fund to pay for the maintenance of the Andersonville Prisoner-of-War Museum in Georgia. SEC. 9. COINAGE PROFIT FUND.

Deposits received from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be deposited in the coinage profit fund. The Secretary shall pay authorized amounts from the fund and charge all expenditures under this Act to the fund.

SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES.

The coins issued under this Act are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund provisions. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting coins. Payment must be received in full, with satisfactory security or guarantee. SEC. 11. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws.
